item.title: By: observerms
item.dc:creator: observerms
item.content:encoded:
I am learning JavaScript. Your blog gives the best example I have found of using _while technique for a binary search.

QUESTION:
where can I find an explanation of how _this works in Line 19:
19 currentElement = this[currentIndex] ;

Thanks from a beginner
observerms

item.title: By: Pedro
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.content:encoded:
function IndexOf(a,v,min,max,mid,f){
min=0,max=a.length,mid=(max+min)>>>1;
while(f=(v!==a[mid]))
if(v>>1)+1;
else min=(mid=(max+min)>>>1)-1;
return f ? -1: mid;
}

item.title: By: Pedro
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.content:encoded:
I’ve made my own binary search method:

function IndexOf(a,v,min,max,mid,f){
min=0,max=a.length,mid=(max+min)>>>1;
while(f=(v!==a[mid]))
if(v>>1)+1;
else min=(mid=(max+min)>>>1)-1;
return f ? -1: mid;
}

item.title: By: Salnikov Stanislav
item.dc:creator: Salnikov Stanislav
item.description: Instead of x / 2 | 0 you can use x >> 1
item.content:encoded: Instead of x / 2 | 0 you can use x >> 1

item.title: By: wesman
item.dc:creator: wesman
item.content:encoded:
I think it actually depends on whether you’re looking at the end, beginning, or middle of the set. I replaced ~currentIndex with…

if (minIndex > currentIndex) {
return ~minIndex;
} else if(maxIndex > currentIndex) {
return ~maxIndex;
}
return ~currentIndex;

This started working for me. Am I right?
